div.head: Peninsular and Oriental S. N. Company.
div.p: Summer Rates will be charged from 2 May to 31 October.

For the convenience of families and others, a large portion of each ship's accommodation has been reserved for Egypt, so that Berths can be definitely engaged at once, as if the voyage were commencing at Port Said. Plans can be seen at the Offices of the Company's Agents.

The through Steamers for Marseilles and London are intended to leave Port Said after the arrival of the 11 a.m. train from Cairo, every Tuesday for the present except the MONGOLIA, which is taking passengers to the Anglo-French Naval Review, and will not wait at Port-Said on 24/25 July. A steam tender will meet the train to convey passengers to the ship.
The Brindisi Express Steamers leave Port Said directly the Indian Mails arrive. Passengers can go on board the evening before. The Fare remains as usual.

div.head: Icilma.
div.p: ARABIC FOR "FLOWS THE WATER."

Icilma Fluor Cream is the only cream that contains no grease nor oil. Deliciously scented it cleanses the pores of the skin as nothing else can do, makes it pearly white, gives life to the tissues, elasticity to the muscles, and a deliciously cool feeling to the skin.

Its unique properties are due to Icilma Natural Water so that it may well be called Nature's Skin Food and the skin requires nothing else to give it the necessary vitality, to preserve it from sunburn, heat, cold or the effects of hard water, to prevent and cure the minor irritations due to overheated blood, and to preserve the youthful fresh look to which hot climates are so fatal.
Invaluable for immediately curing mosquito and insect bites and for greatly preventing them.

div.head: The Plague
div.p: Today's plague bulletin reports one recovery in hospital at Alexandria.

div.head: The Egyptian University
div.p: The third list of subscription for the scheme of the proposed opiversity amounts to L E. 800, the total som now being 1. E. 7,535.
The Brindisl Mall.
Ordinary corresponder ce for despatch by the Port Said Brindini route will be made up at the GPO, Alexandria, at 3.10 p.m. on Sunday.
Covernment School Diplomas.
The diploms accorded to pupils of the Normal School at Nasrich will in future be considered as eqnal to that of the Secondary Schools.
Mecca Water Supply
The Emir of Mecos reports that the repair ing of the water conduits is being very actively carried on, and that several hundred metres are already in order.
"Trotter Egyption."
The first trotting races to be held at Cairo this season will take place daring the middle of next month at the Egyptian Trotting Club's grounds at Rod el Parag.
The Bouino Avenue.
The Tanzim Service is about to pull down a number of buildings at the east end of the Boulac-avenue with the objeot of widening tho | road and making a square.
Army of Oooupation.
A board of offisers will assemble in the office of the G. 0. C. in Egypt, at 11 a.m. on Saturday, 20th inst., to consider the estimates of the command for the financial year 1907-8.
Pilgrimage.
A party of Italian pilgrims to the Holy Land, under the leadership of Archbishop Radini, left yesterday for Messina and Naples by the S.S. Singapore, of the Italian Navige-T tion Co. .
A Fatal Operation.

The Zsgazig Tribunal bas condemned Dr. Kat.fi Effendi Mobamed, who operated upon * woman at the time of child-birth, to fine of LB. 50 and L.E. 100 damages to the woman's relations for having caused her death thereby
Execution at Assiout.

Sadik Ahmed Salim, a native of Nag Hilali, Ghirgeb Mondirieb, who was sentenced to death on the 25th Joly last for the murder of his two brothers on the 11th May, was 12 executed on Wednesday in the prison of Assiout Moodirieb.
Sirdar's Island.

In our announcement of the sale of Sirdar's Island, Asronan, to the Government, we omitted to mention that the transaction bad boen oarried out through the instrumentality of Mr. George Mitobell, of Assouan. The island has been acquired by the Ministry of Pinanoe.
Ineffootho Banishment

"Al Monyad" reports that Alexander Kudai, who was recently banished to Greece in oom-1 pany with George Arakgi, after an imprisonment of 21 days, for their violent attack opon Abdin police officers, bas returned to Cairo, where he may be met in the streets at any time of the day.
Austrian Lloyd S. N. CO.

Mr. Gino P. Milani has been appointed agent for the advertisements on the Austrian Lloyd steamers for Egypt, the Sadan, and the Lavant. Owing to the popularity of the Austrian Lloyd steamers and the enormous number of tourists who como here by this line the necessity of advertising on these steamers is obvious.
Ungrateful "Patriots."

The unfriendly attitude of the so-called Egyptian Patriots is the blackest ingratitude, for even the most bitter enemy of Great Britain will bave to admit that the prosperity, wealth, Ponce, security, and liberty enjoyed by the Egyptians of to-day under British role ia unprecedented in the s ale of the Nile country. --Professor Vambéry, in "Independent." New York.
Destrutive Fire

News somes of a destructive fire at Boni Mazar, which destroyed M M Ghabrial's stores. 800 bales of 807 kantars of cotton, valued at LE. 2,600, were lost, with 400 empty bales and cheq:09, sbares, eto., worth LE. 8000. The fire opfortunately spread to the store owned by Mobammad Abdallah and Judab Bl Gaied, where it destroyed 100 bales, worth about LB. 600.
Suez Canal

On the 15 and 16th October 21 vessels, of which 10 were northward and 11 south ward bound, transited the canal, and paid for transit and passenger toll Fr. 599,414.91. Of these 13 were Britisb, 4 German, 1 Russian, 1 Italian and 2 Freneb. The total receipts since October 1 are Fr. 4,338 203.99, and during that time 161 vessels transited the canal, 69 being northward, and 92 southward bound.
Nativo, and Military Cast-offe.

An Army Order has been issued to the effect that the practice of selling uniform clothing to datives is strictly forbidden. No soldier is permitted to dispose of his old clothing except to the authorised contractor. The G. 0. div.p: PORTENTOUS FIGURES.
INTERNATIONAL CONFERENCE.

The House of Commons showed daring its last session that it intended to at last pay some attention to the conduet of affairs in Egypt and the Sodan, and one of the most vital matters about which questions were asked was the import of spirituous liquors into the Sudad. There appear to be a tondonoy to resent any animadversion made on Beyptian matters in the House of Commons, as though the management of this country shjuld be immune from oriticism, but all well wishers of the country sbonld welcome any le intelligent interest that is manifested.

There was a series of questions asked re 1 cently in the House of Commons on the subject alluded to above, which were of the utmost importance to the fature welfare oft the Sudan. In Lord Cromer's Sadan Report for 1901 be stated that he had drawn the attention of Sir Reginald Wingate to the large amount of spirits imported during 1900 into the Sudan. It then amounted to LE. 8,400 (250 tons). Last year the importa under the head of "Liquors" showed an enormous increase in five years, and were valued at LÉ 81,000. The matter will be taken up 1 seriously, it is to be borel, at the International Conference, at which fourteon Powers having colonies or interests in Africa are represented, now mosting at Brussels, to deliberate upon and devise means of controlliog the sale of alebolic liquors in Afrion, and this in view of the fatal or serious results arising from their immoderate use by the native population. The last conference was held in 1899. Questions in Parliamont.
The attitade of the Foreign Offise in this most vital question for the Sadan is not very illuminating and it is sincerely to be hoped that the House of Commons will keep an eye 1 on the matter.

Wo append the text of three questions, I which were asked in the House during last Jane. On the 12th of that month, Sir H. Cotton (Nottingham) asked the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs "whether he will farnish or procuro information showing in detail and me far as possible the places of origin and the quantities and values of spirituous liquors imported into the Sadan via Wady Halfa daring the several years 1900, 1901, 1902, 1903, 1904 and 1905, supplementing the statements made in Lord Cromer's annual Reports on Egypt and the Sadan to the effect that 950 tons (valued at £8,400) were imported in 1900, 241 tons in It 1901, 326 tons in 1902, 561 tons (valued at £119,738), in 1904, and a quantity not stated but valued at £84,000 in 1905, and whether he is in a position to explain the increase in the quantity of spirits so imported.

The Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs (Sir Bdward Gray), replied: We have no intormation on the subject other than that contained in Lord Cromer's reports, but Lord Cromer will be asked if he can give the farther infor mation asked for.

Sir H. Cotton: I beg to ask the Secretary of State for Foreign Aftairs whether any, and, if 80, what steps have been taken with reference to Lord Cromer's statements in bis annual reports on the finance, administration, and condition of Egypt and the Sadan, to the effect that in 1900 he had drawn Sir Reginald Wingate's attention to the large amount of spirits which seemed to have been imported into the Sadan (od. 1012), page 63, and that in 1904 Sir Reginald Wingate's attention bad been drawn to the enormous increase in the quantities of spirits fioding their way to Uganda via the White Nile, and that the sale of liquors in the Sadan should be carefally watebed, and if necessary controlled, (od. 2409) page 122, | Sir Blward Grey: From Lord Cromer's an nual reports it is evident that this matter is receiving his careful attention. Inquiry will be made as to the precise answer to the bon. member's question. The Brussels Act.

Dr. Ratherford (Middlesex, Brentford) : I beg to ask the Secretary of State for Foreign Affairs whether he will state what action has been taken, in accordance with article 12 of the Anglo-Bgyptian Agreement of 1899, in which the contracting parties undertak, to psy special attention to the enforcement of the Brussels Act of 189) prohibiting the importation or manufacture of spirituous liquors in the region of the zone wbere, on account of religions, or from other motives, the use of distilled ligaors does not exist, or has not been developed

Sir Edward Grey : The Government of the Sudan bave drawn up various regulations for controlling and licensing the import and sale of alcoholio liquors in their territory. These regulations have been modified and added to from time to time, and the matter is one which engages the constant attention of the Sudanese Government.
SUNDAY AT KHARTOUM.
"Enquirer" writes to the London "Tribune" :

The Sirdar bas recently called attention to the Building Fund for the English Caorch at Khartoum, and the occasion seems a favour able one for raising the question whether Sunday ehoold not be observed there as the day of rest instead of Friday. The latter day is believed to have been chosen out of consideratio, fir the Muhamedan people; but is it against the Mohamedan faith to work on Friday? If not, it serms a great pity to de. throne the Christian Sonday and make it an ordinary working day.

div.head: LORD KITCHENER IN TEARS
div.p: A KHARTOUM EPISODE.

An interesting work, entitled With Lord Kitchener against the Mabdi," will abortly be published by Berlin poblishing house. The writer, Major Adolf von Tiedemand, who aocompanied the Sodan expedition as ropre ner tative of the Berlin General Staff, gives the following impressions :

"Lord Kitobener's lack of consideration is well known, and for just that reason, although N'mired and respected, be is unpopular with other officers. On the day fixed for the colobration in Khartoum, the company bad been ordered to be in readiness by six a.m. Wo stood hoor After hour, but po Sirdar arrived. Bight o'clock came and want, and then the sun began to born. Appearing, however, at nine o'clock, Lord Kitchener wonton board his gonbont withont a single word of excuse or explanation.

"Later we learned from one of his adjatante that it bad occurred to him soddenly that morning that he had not yet visited the wounded in hospital, so there he bad gone without bothering himself about anything else. Roason for Unpopularity.

"Another reasOD, perhape, for his unpopalar ity is that when off duty' ho keeps aloof from the familiar intercourse which so often existe among English officers of very different rank. He is body and soul a soldier, and his military instincta tell him that this cannot be right. I had an impression that it pleased him when I maintained that respect for superiors which we knew so well in Germany. Kitobenor often called me to him during the maroh and con veraed about military conditions in the Father land.

"I seldom saw Lord Kitebener riding at gallop during a battle, but when he did, oven over places covered with great stoner, he rode like an export horseman. He is held to be one of the best horaemen in an army where overy officer is more or less a good rider.

"Without in the least being guilty of bravado, the Sirdar seemed absolutely insensible to personal danger. The entrance of Omdarman was not much less than a mad| piece of bravery. His coolness had something humorous in it. For instance, opoe when the gans were roaring away, Kitchener stopped to light his cigarette, quito anooncerned-in fact, carefully noting which way the wiod blew.

"On his way to Bogland, after the campaign, he said, "Now oomes the worst part of the war, and truly be had more borror of banquets, harrahs, and receptions than of the heat, dirt, and stink of the Sadan.

"The Sirdar had overcome the enemy and seized the prize afters years of work and privation. He had crashed Mahdigm and avenged Gordon. Bat as the hero stood on the rains of Gordon's house, while the flags flew and the cannon thundered, be could not repress his foeliage, and the tears rolled down his weather. brou zad face. Happy the man to whom such an hour of life is given !"

SULTAN'S SON AS POLICE
SUPERVISER

The Saltan, having no longer the physical strength to carry on alone the duty of going through the affairs that are daily submitted to bim, bas (says the Constantinople correspondont of the "Manchester Guardian") brought in his son Prince Barbadeddid as his regular assistant

Bat fearing that the immediate participation of this Prince in the der patch of political and official matters whicb are really business of State wi hout the way baving been prepared, and at a moment when Burbaneddin is as yet without official title and the coup d'etat is still only in the air, would infallibly Jead to complications at home as well as in Tarkey's foreign relations, Abdul Hamid bas thought it best to begin by getting rid of one part of his burden, and has eatrusted his son with the supervision of the secret police and with the task of going through the 5,000 reports of spies wbich, without eraggeration, reach bim on an average every day.

div.head: THE LATEST "AROCITY."
div.p: MR. BLUNTS MATARIEH ESTATE.

Mr. Wilfrid Blant is not above taking fall advantage of the work of Lord Cromer in Egypt when it comes to a matter of pounds, sbillings, and pence. Part of bis estate at Matarieh bas already been parcelled off in building sites and Dumber of such sold, possibly to speculators who bope to get rid of them to others at bigher price than they paid for them. | These lands, which are desert pure and simple, were porohased a few years ago for a few napoleons the feddan. They are now being effered to the publio generally at the rate of L.B. 809 tbe feddap. There is nothing atrocious in Mr. Blunt taking advantage of the boom and dieposing, for L.B. 40,000 or LR. 50,000, of lands which possibly oost him as many half piastres, but there is something very much bordering upon a real and up-to-dato "atrocity" in the laying oat of these desirable sites for wetry reajdonoon.

The main roads on the Blunt property aro five metres wide and the by-roads foer metres only. Oa the building sites immediately adj aing the Blont property the main roads are 16 metres wide and the by-roads sither 10 or 12 metres. How those viotimised into buying building sites on the Blunt property are to provide footpaths on each side of even the main rɔads and leave room for hand barrow to get in with their goods and obattale, good. pool only knows. And is it not time that the attention of the Poblio Hoalth Department and the Pablio Worka Department abould be called to the mattar? To pormit of a few handred houses being ran op in a new district with nothing but alley.ways a DONDS of oom. monioation appears to be inviting an epidemio at the first favourable opportunity, and this 80 that Mr. Blant or his agents may squeeze the poople of his adopted country ont of the attermost farthing to be got för bis precious desert lande.
A RADICAL ON LORD CROMER.

Mr. Harold Spender, writing on "Bogland, Bgypt and Tarkay," in the current "Contem. porary Review," holds that strong or exooptional measures should be directed not so much against the tollaheen as against the Tarkish agitators or Bgyptians in the pay of the Turke. Coming from the pen of so strong a Radicalm Mr. Sponder, his testimony to the wisdom, the ondaring påtiedon, and the justice of Lord Cromer's role is very remarkable. As Mr. Spender well pats it:

"We have achieved their (the Egyptian peasantry':) happine88 ; we must work patient. ly for their loyalty. We have no reason to be a bamed of our record. We have respected the Moslem religion, observed the Moslem Friday, taught the Koran in oor soboole, and given to Moslems a preference both on the bench and in the Civil Service. We must not be tarred aside from this straight course. Wo. must wean the Egyptians from the Turk, not wrench them. The world has enough cages for black men. A sollen and cowed population would be a heavy price to pay for our continued oooupation-- sad ending to a great and glorious page in our history. It would be a real triumph for the Sultan. For what we really bave to defend from him is not our power, which he cannot touch, bat oor British justice, sanity and mercy."
THB £ 3,900 ROBBERY.
The Coptio olerk apod whom føll the doty of registering the letter containing £ 3,900 from the Anglo-Egyptian Bank is now under arrest, and the inquiry is being continued.

It is well to note that in the very great majority of instances the banks are content with registering packages containing some of money to no matter what value. The reason for this is not far to seek. By registration only £? can be recovered and by insurance L.B.400. It is therefore no advantage to the banks to register or insure with the Post Office and they consequently insare to the foll amount with some insurance company.

By the regulations of the Post Office the public are bound to insure and declare "papers of value, such as paper money, doods of sale, deeds of loan, interest and dividend warrants, mortgage deads, etc.," and we would therefore Suppose that the Post Office cannot be held legally responsible, as their conditions were not folfilled.
INTERESTING APPEAL.

Among the ones that will be shortly beard by the Mixed Court of_Appeal is a double appeal brought by the Egyptian Government Railways and by the beirs of the late Me. Acbille Albrecht against the judgment of the Cairo Mixed Tribunal ordering the former to pay an indemnity of L.E. 10,000 to the latter.

The Administration maintains that the accident was due to the victim's fault, and demands a complete discharge from the obliga tions imposed upon it by the Cairo Mixed Court of 1 st Instance. On the other band, tho beirs declare the indemnity allotted them in the first instance to be insufficient and demand its indrease.
Me. Scbiarabati Bey will represent the Administration and Me. Labsobnwill plead for the boirs.

div.head:
THREATENED JEHAD.
FANATICISM IN NORTH AFRICA.

div.p: The anti French agitation in Morocco con tinues unabated. General Liautoy, commanding in Algeria, telegraphs that preparations are being made for a boly war. The tribes have selected Wady Gbir as a choron point for concentration. The Sultan's cousin, Malai, has paid them a visit and induced them to suspend their intestine guarrels with a view to taking the field.
(Pouter)

div.head:
MAYORAL VISIT TO PARIS.
M. BOURGEOIS'S SPEECH.

div.p: A reception was beld at the Foreigo Office in bonour of the Lord Mayor, who, however, was iodisposed and was replaced by Sir Joseph Knight. M. Bourgeois, proposing a toast, mid that the entente which Paris was non oplobrating was not only the result of an agroomont between the two GovernBents, but slso the constant rapprochement of the two public opinions. It was the co-operation of the wills of the two nations that gave tbo Aoglo Prenob entente its deep significanoo.
Sir Francis Bertio replied thanking tho Minister in the name of the British Government for bio reference to the entente.
The Lord Mayor, later on, was present at the Ofers.
(Router)

div.head:
THE KOBPENICH ROBBERY.
ABSURDITY OF GERMAN MILITARISM.

div.p: The amazing audacity and thoroughness of tbe Koepenick coup de main hos diverted the attention of the whole of Germany to the readiness with which the Imperial troops and the whole of the local police force obeyed the bogos csptain. The absolute sobmission of all the victims to the supposed Imperial order is regarded as the reduction to absordity of German militarism.

Later. The boar is the engrossing topio of tbe day. The police are in possession of the photograph of the bogos captain, wo is a clever swindler and bae already served several years' penal servitude. His uniform bas been discovered on the south side of the city.
(Reuter)

div.head:
ENGLISH HELP FOR THE LUTIN
BERESPORD SENDS MEN OP WAR

div.p: Lord Charles Beresford has sent a battleship, a cruiser, and a destroyer to help to salve the Lotin. It is feared that the crew has perished, and there is little hope of raising the boat.
(Reuter)
The spontaneity of Lord Charles Beresford's assistance in the case of the sunken submarine is greatly appreciated in France. The Admirall at Bizerta has telegraphed to him his warm thanks.
(Router)
The divers report that the Lotin is lying broadside on sand bed at a depth of 36 metres. No answer was obtainable from the crew.
(Honso)

div.head:
TURKISH SUCCESSION
CHANGE IN GERMANY'S ATTITUDE.
div.p: I am informed, from an undeniably trustworthy source (Sys the "Tribune" Paris Correspondent), that the attitude of Germany towards the question of the Torkish succession has been completely modified. It is of public notoriety that the Berlin Chaneellery favoured the Palace intrigues at Constantinople for the substitution of Barhaneddin Effendi, the fourth son of Abdul Hamid, for Resbad Effendi, Abdul Hamid's brother, who is the rightful heir to the throne in accordance with the tradition, dating back as far as 1617, that the eldest member of the Imperial family shall alway occupy the throne. Burhaneddin Effendi, who was educated in Germany, and is said to be a favourite with the Emperor William, was, rightly or wrongly, regarded as likely, if he succeeded his father, to further the realization of Gorman ambitions in both European and Asiatic Turkey, to the detriment of the interests of the other Powers.

The idea of altering the order of soccession baving met with determined opposition in the Ottoman Empire itself, and the German Government having probably recognized that it had but little chance of success, the German Chancellery has now abandoned its project, and is seeking to propitiate the Liberal Torks by favoaring the idea of the adoption of a constitutional régime under the rightful sovereign.

In this connexion it is of importance to note the testimony which comes from all the politioal parties in Constantinople relative to the growing and now, it is believed, irresistible movement in favour of a Constitutional Government. Perhaps the most convincing proof of the strength of that movement which I have seen was contained in a letter from a bigb official of the Porto to Haydar Midhat Bey. "Will you follow the ideas of your fatber," it ran, "and take the lead of the movement of the Ulemas ? If you will, it is cortain that the great majority of the people will support you. There is no doubt that Rashad Effendi, on coming to tbe throne, will revive the Midhat Constitution, which, however, requires modification, additions, and retrenchments. I beg you to inform me of your ideas on those points, because if you will undertake the work you will to morrow be to Turkey what Kossuth was to Hungary. The application of Constitution is not, however, enough. It is requisite to adopt other reforms, and it is also to realize them that you can work usefolly for your bis country. Will you undertake this difficult but eminently patriotic task?"

div.head: RAMADAN TRADITION.
div.p: Ramadan is the ninth Mohamedan month, and fast of thirty days, and begins as soon as it has been established tbat the new moon bas been seen by a Moslem. If a cloudy sky interiferos, it sbould begin after counting thirty fall days from tbe 1st of Shaaban, or in these days by announor ment by telegram from Constantipople or elsewhere that the fast has been proclaimed by proper authority. The observance! of the fast is one of the five pillars of practice in Islam. Men and women slike are er joined to observe it; all, in fact, wbo are of sofficient Cablage and strengtb. Ezemptions include sick persone, women about to be confined or giving nourishment, and travellers ; but there should only temporarily excuse themselves, and sbould make op the pumber of days by fasting, if able to do so, in other months. The daily fast begins from the time wben a black can be distinguished from a white tbread, and ends at sunset. During Ramadan tradition states that the gates of Paradise are open, and tbe gates of Hell closed, all devils being chained. It is interesting to stroll at night in the streets during Ramadan, and amongst the cafés wbere the romanoes of Abu Z-yd, 'Antar, ero, are being recited. Those who desire to herr some of the best munshids of Cairo should visit in the evening the courtyard of the house of the Sheikh el Bakti or of the Sheikh el 'Aruseh, in which zikrs are performed every night, and which they are generally made welcome to enter, by the courtesy of tha Sheikhs. On the 13th, 14th, and 27th visits should be made to 18. tbe Mo que of Mobammed 'Ali, in the Citadel, eberan, between 8 and 10 pm. This mo'h is styled El Mubarek ('the Blessed').

div.head: WEAK LUNGS
div.p: An Unsuspected Evil developed
with alarming rapidity. Prostrated; Racked with Pain.
Young Man's Collapse cured by DR. WILLIAMS' PINK PILLS.

"I had never suspected that my lungs were not strong, so, when I first felt a sharp pain in my side, a kind of stitch, I took little notice, thinking it would quickly vanish." But Mr. Albert Morris, who resides at 3, Lodbury. mews North, Ledbury-road, Bayswater, W., has good reason to remember those warnings of approaching lung troubles.

"With this acute pain," he continued, "I felt breathless and dreadfully worn out during the day; yet a long night's sleep did not refresh me, and when the pain became worse a doctor was called in. By this time I could breathe only with difficulty, and work was too much for me ; at last I had to take to my bed. Then the doctor told me that pleurisy had developed, I was racked with pain, and as I lay in bed, scarcely able to turn, parched and living on morsels of nourishment, it seemed that I was doomed to suffer without hope of relief.

"My mother urged me to try Dr. Williams' | Pink Pills for Pale People, for they had cured her of a long-standing complaint. So I yielded to her advice and took the pills; in a short time a slight improvement was noticeable. The pains were not so acute, and I seemed to have gained strength. The dull heavy feeling of weakness began to leave me, and as I continued Dr. Williams' Pink Pills, my health gradually improved and the pains vanished,
Before long I was about again, quite cured, and I returned to my work after several weeks'absence, a hale, healthy man. Dr. Williams' Pink Pills had put me on my legs. .
"I have never had a return of lung troubles, and I am in better health now than I have ever been before. I am not afraid of a breakdown now that I know what Dr. Williams' Pink Pills will do."
Mrs Morris added her own experience : -

"For six years," she said, "I had not been free from indigestion It was like a shadow over my life. I had constant headaches with dreadful pains in the stomach, though I didn't eat enough to keep a sparrow alive. I grew pale and thin and weak; sometimes I could scarcely get my breath.
"When I took Dr. Williams' Pink Pills the headaches vanished, the pains lessened, and with a few boxes I was quite cured of indiges
By making rich, good blood with every dose that is bow Dr. Williams' Pink Pills for Pale People achieve so many remarkable ** cures, including Anæmia, Indigestion, General

Weakness, Nervous Disorders. Headaches, Neuralgia, Rheumatism, Sciatica, St. Vitus' Dance, Paralysis, and women's ills. Alexandrie, Le Caire, Port-Said
Le Crédit Lyonnais fait toutes opérations de banque, telles que:
Ouverture de comptes courants contre dépôts de valeurs;
Emission de traites et chèques, émission de lettres de Crédit, paiement par télégraphe sur les principales villes de la France et de l'étranger;
Garde de titres;
Recourvement d'effets sur l'Egypte et l'étranger;
Le Crédit Lyonnais reçoit des fonds ou un compte de dépôt et délivre des bons à échéance fixe aux taux suivants:
2% aux bons de 1 an et au-delà.
